description: From c.1400, from Middle English sent (noun) and senten (verb), from Old French sentir (“to feel, perceive, smell”), from Old French sentire "to feel, perceive, sense", from Latin sentīre, present active infinitive of sentiō. Ultimately from Proto-Indo-European *sent- (“to feel”), and thus related to Dutch zin (“sense, meaning”), German Sinn (“sense”), Low German Sinn (“sense”), Luxembourgish Sënn (“sense, perception”), Saterland Frisian Sin (“sense”), West Frisian sin (“sense”). The -c- appeared in the 17th century, possibly by influence of ascent, descent, etc., or by influence of science.

examples: Synonyms: aroma, bouquet, fragrance, nosegay, odor, perfume, redolence, smell
the scent of flowers / of a skunk
to give off / release / exude a scent
to breathe in / inhale a scent

entries.meaning: A smell left by an animal that may be used for tracing.
examples: The dogs picked up / caught the scent but then quickly lost it.
Synonym: olfaction
I believe the bloodhound has the best scent of all dogs.

entries.meaning: (chiefly uncountable) A substance (usually liquid) created to provide a pleasant smell.
examples: Synonyms: aftershave, cologne, eau de toilette, perfume, toilet water
a scent shop
a scent bazaar

entries.meaning: (figuratively) Any trail or trace that can be followed to find something or someone, such as the paper left behind in a paperchase.
examples: The minister's off-hand remark put journalists on the scent of a cover-up.
The tip put the detectives on a false / the wrong scent.
to pick up a scent / get scent of something ― discover one of a series of clues in the trail of evidence
to throw / put someone off the scent ― distract them from following the trail of evidence

verbs.description: scent (third-person singular simple present scents, present participle scenting, simple past and past participle scented)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To detect the scent of; to discern by the sense of smell.
examples: Synonym: smell
The hounds scented the fox in the woods.

entries.meaning: (transitive, intransitive) To inhale in order to detect the scent of (something).
examples: Synonyms: sniff, smell

entries.meaning: (transitive, figurative) To have a suspicion of; to detect the possibility of (something).
examples: Synonyms: detect, discern, perceive, sense
I scented trouble when I saw them running down the hill towards me.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To impart an odour to, to cause to have a particular smell.
examples: Synonyms: perfume, odorize
Scent the air with burning sage before you begin your meditation.

entries.meaning: (intransitive, obsolete) To have a smell; (figuratively) to give an impression (of something).
examples: Synonym: smell

entries.meaning: To hunt animals by means of the sense of smell.
